AL.note: Limited home-rule/local legislation possible; localities can affect tax base in some cases. Verify city/parish codes.

AK.note: No statewide general sales tax; many localities levy their own sales taxes and set taxability locally.

AZ.note: Cities/counties may impose local privilege taxes with some differences in tax base; local variation exists.

AR.note: Taxability is set at state level; locals generally only add rates.

CA.note: California state law defines taxability; locals add district/local rates but do not generally change taxability categories.

CO.note: Many home-rule municipalities — localities in Colorado can have different tax bases; check city ordinances.

CT.note: Taxability determined at state level; localities do not change the tax base.

DE.note: No statewide sales tax; not applicable for local sales-tax modifiers in the usual sense.

FL.note: State defines taxability; counties add surtaxes (rates) but generally do not change taxability categories.

GA.note: State defines taxability; however, local sales taxes (county) are applied to food in practice — double-check local rules for rate application.

HI.note: Hawaii uses an excise tax structure; taxability is state-determined (locals do not change the tax base).

ID.note: Taxability set by state; locals may not change categories.

IL.note: State sets tax base; home-rule sales tax in IL concerns rates (home-rule rate authority) but generally follows state taxability definitions.

IN.note: State taxability rules are statewide; locals add rate components only.

IA.note: Taxability is state-level; local rates apply but generally do not change taxable categories.

KS.note: State determines taxability; locals generally limited to rate changes.

KY.note: Taxability set by state statutes; localities add rates only.

LA.note: Parishes/municipalities have local-option tax authority and may create variations in tax base in some cases; check parish ordinances.

ME.note: State sets taxability; localities do not alter tax base.

MD.note: Taxability statewide; counties/cities add rate but do not change categories.

MA.note: Taxability determined at state level; localities do not change the tax base.

MI.note: State defines taxability; local rate add-ons only.

MN.note: State-level taxability; localities add rates but not categories.

MS.note: Taxability is determined by state law; locals typically affect rates only.

MO.note: Generally state-determined taxability; some local exceptions exist but primarily rate changes — verify municipal codes if needed.

MT.note: No statewide sales tax; local resort/municipal taxes exist but taxability is not broadly modified by local law.

NE.note: State sets taxability; local option is mainly rate-based.

NV.note: State taxability rules apply statewide; locals add rates.

NH.note: No general sales tax; meals/rooms taxes are state-administered — locals do not change tax base broadly.

NJ.note: State sets taxability; local rate components are limited (no county sales tax system like others).

NM.note: Gross receipts tax is state-administered; municipalities administer and may have local rate differences but tax base is largely state-defined.

NY.note: New York State sets taxability but New York City and some counties have nuanced local rules (e.g., NYC prepared food treatment) — check NYC/county guidance.

NC.note: State determines taxability; local rates vary but categories follow state law.

ND.note: Taxability set at state level; local rates only.

OH.note: State-level taxability; some localities have special taxes but usually do not change the taxable categories.

OK.note: Municipalities in Oklahoma may have local sales-tax rules and some local differences in treatment historically — verify municipal codes.

OR.note: No statewide sales tax; Oregon's bottle bill exists; localities generally do not create separate taxability rules.

PA.note: State defines taxable categories; some counties (e.g., Allegheny/Philadelphia) may have local tax structures but taxability generally follows state law.

RI.note: Taxability statewide; locals do not alter categories.

SC.note: Recent precedent/changes allow certain local divergences in some states like SC — verify county/city rules for outlier cases.

SD.note: Taxability set by state; local rates apply but categories are statewide.

TN.note: State level determines taxability; local option taxes affect rates.

TX.note: Taxability is set by state statute; most localities only add rates — isolated municipal exceptions are rare; verify city ordinances when in doubt.

UT.note: State sets taxability, localities add rates/districts but do not typically change categories.

VT.note: Taxability defined by state law; local variations not common.

VA.note: State defines taxability; localities primarily add rate components.

WA.note: State-level taxability; local sales/use taxes exist but taxable categories are set by state.

WV.note: Taxability set statewide; locals add rates only.

WI.note: State taxability definitions apply statewide; local rates apply but categories are state-defined.

WY.note: State determines taxability; local rates may apply in some resort/local contexts but categories are statewide.

DC.note: DC sets its own taxability; no subordinate local jurisdictions.
sources: DC Office of Tax and Revenue
